item.title: .Site.Title
item.description: Principles of Design Sets of agreed-upon rules which help govern the way design decisions are made, usually to achieve some purpose. Examples I know Interaction design [[Calm Technology]]

item.title: .Site.Title
item.description: Considers not just the website, product, or item created, but also the people, connections, and processes involved. Related to journey mapping. The journey ends when the customer moves on from the relationship.

item.title: .Site.Title
item.description: Typeface classifications The difference between Latin typeface classification and other languages

item.title: .Site.Title
item.description: Calm technology A set of principles of interaction design that seeks to reduce user attention, focus, and other principles typically lauded and misused for addictive purposes. Calm technology is a direct response to the idea of “delight” having gone too far, and hopes to achieve an excellent user experience by creating a supportive environment, where the technology only interrupts or seeks attention as needed. It also hopes to solve the problem with the least technological interference possible.

item.title: .Site.Title
item.description: Packaging In InDesign, packaging refers to the process of collecting all the assets related to a file, such as images and fonts, and combining them into one folder. It’s usually used for sending a file to another designer or to print, because assets usually aren’t embedded directly in InDesign files to help improve their performance.

item.title: .Site.Title
item.description: Interaction Design Tools Tools you could use to create interactions between humans and computer systems. Examples I know [[Augmented Reality]] [[Internet of Things]] [[Virtual Reality]]
